description.text:
I decided to make a LA Kings Coaster set.  
The base is wide enough to hold 5 coasters, it will fit a little snug though.  
The LA Kings logo was used from TinkerCad, modified to work with what I wanted to use it for.

Everything is printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator Dual Coaster is printed with the following settings,
Layer Height - 0.20mm
Infill - 15%
Number of Shells - 2 Base is printed with the following settings,
Layer Height - 0.20mm
Infill - 15%
Number of Shells - 2

The Orginal Z-Axis Support can be adjustet with the normal screw nut. With a trapezoidal thread this is not possible. The endsupport at the top can not be adjusted with the spindel in place.
This design ist much stronger and the Screw to fix the Bracket is accessible with the spindel in place, so you can adjust thr upper bearing to unload the stepper Motor.
The new Version V1 with a diameter of 22.1 mm should fit perfect with a 608 Ball bearing. This is a makeover from 3DFranky's K8200 Z-Endsupport (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:175137)
I was not satisfied with the original design.
Additional i added a piece for mounting an endstop-switch.

author: misha12

description.text:
This is a fan holder for a 50mm x 50mm x 11mm fan. It was inspired by this thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8183 I made it because I could not find the right current setting for my stepper driver to keep the motors cool, and not lose steps. I've added a butchered heatsink to improve the cooling capacity.
Now my X stepper stays cool, and doesn't mis a step! As an added bonus, there's a hole for the wires. The Y heatsink doesn't need a fan because it's bigger.
It's held in place by a suitably edited large paperclip.

• Find right fan / hack scad file to adjust for your fan.
  • Print holder
  • Mount heatsink to stepper (I've added some Artic Silver thermal compound from my overclocking days between the motor and the heatsink for even better cooling performance. It's held in place by tie-wraps and paperclips until it falls off ;-) )
  • Clip holder on ultimaker
  • Connect fan to power
  • print more and faster with cooler motors!

title: Prusa i3 Z axis top ends

description.text:
My take on Z axis top ends for the Prusa i3 for using with 8 mm lead screws and 608ZZ (22 mm) bearings.  
Still a work in progress

comments.text: Terrible mod. Do not do this. The bottom of the z rod is mounted on the motor. There is a top rod holder that moves with Z height. Forcing the very top of the Z rod into this bearing means you now have 3 mount points and that will cause stress on the motor. If it was supposed to be rigid on the top, it would have been done that way in the original design.
comments.author: Jason3030

Thousand Character Classic Bead - 005
Chinese Characters
Meditation bead for training and learning. 千字文
The Thousand Character Classic (also known as the Thousand Character Text) is a Chinese poem used as a primer for teaching Chinese characters to children from the sixth century onward. It contains exactly one thousand characters, each used only once, arranged into 250 lines of four characters apiece and grouped into four line rhyming stanzas to make it easy to memorize.

description.text: I created this tool to help calibrate the tool offset between dual extruders heads. This design was inspired by this thread http://forum.makergear.com/viewtopic.php?f=13&t=2747

This is a Vernier scale, where each line represents a shift of 0.05 mm. Print this with two extruders and see at what point in the scale they align. If your offset is exact the alignment should be around the middle (long) line.

This is a nice little puzzle.  It is easy to print (Box, Box Top, and a set of 8 Sticks) with no supports and with minimal, if any, post-print finishing - mine have required no post-print finishing at all.  The Puzzle looks deceptively easy to solve, but it turns out to be a genuine challenge for many (if not most) people.  I thought it would be an “Easy-Peasy”puzzle, but maybe not so much!  These would make great Holiday, or Birthday gifts for anyone who enjoys a good puzzle.  They look great and provide at least a modest challenge.  
I've been printing them in a variety of colors, and I think the 'transparent filaments' look particularly nice.  I've also been printing the Box and Box Top in one color and the Sticks in a contrasting color.  
Since the puzzle looks so basic, and the solution appears (at first at least) to be quite straightforward, most people find it interesting to tinker with the puzzle and come back to it over and over until they finally do solve it (or until you give them a little hint).  
Solution:  The correct solution requires placing all 8 Sticks into the Box with each Stick lying flat on the bottom of the Box.  No Stick can be tilted up, not even a tiny bit.  Then the Box Top will easily fit back on the Box with all 8 Sticks comfortably inside.  Trust me, there is plenty of room in the Box for all 8 Sticks when they are arranged correctly.  
Please Note:  Although I have not provided the solution here, I will respond to personal Thingiverse messages with questions about part sizes and/or printing accuracy.   If you have trouble solving the puzzle once you have printed it, you can message me your email address, and I’ll send you the Solution Photo by return email.  You may be surprised. . .  Or, I can respond to your inquiry with a little ‘hint’ if you prefer.  I will not use your email address for any other purpose, nor share it with anyone else.  I promise.  
Feel free to contact me with questions, comments, or suggestions.  I would also like to have anyone who “Makes” this puzzle, thank me by taking a moment respond with “I Made One” with your puzzle’s photo and your comments.  
Have Fun!  
-mike-  
PS: If you like this puzzle, you may want to take a look at my other, very similar, "Dyn-O-Mite Puzzle".  Same concept, but with round Sticks instead of square ones.  I’m not sure if one of them may be easier to solve than the other, but both print nicely and are very similar.    -m-

UPDATE:  I'm now printing my Square Deal Puzzles with the following changes:  Box and Top: Infill=10%, Shells=2; and  Sticks: Infill=0%, Shells=2.  This produces a puzzle that is still quite strong and gives the Sticks a nice light feel.  It also reduces print times quite a bit, and all the parts look great with Translucent Filaments.
I printed all the parts of the puzzle, using PLA Filament, on a MakerBot Replicator 5th Gen Printer using the following settings: "Standard" Presets; Infill=25%; Layer Height=0.20mm; Shells=3; Raft=Yes; Supports=No.  These settings produced very nice puzzles in a reasonable amount of time.  
I printed the “Box” and “Box Top” using True Brown (and other colors), and the “Sticks” using True Blue (and other colors).  Print times were: Box=4h 1m; Box Top=1h 54m; Stick Set=4h 0m.  I put the finished puzzle in a small zip-lock bag with all but the smallest piece in the Box; I added the little Puzzle Teaser Note; and I included the smallest Stick in the bag, but outside of the Box.  See my Photos.  
I have printed a dozen of these puzzles at this point – they make great gifts and are fun to keep around as table top toys for friends and family visitors.  They take a little while to print, but none of them has required any post-print finishing.  The Box Top fits a tightly onto the Box the first time you put them together, but they loosen up nicely after a couple of cycles.  Just make sure to install and remove the Box Top by pushing it straight down and pulling it straight up (and not by tilting it, which may break off one of the small ‘pins’).  
I included separate files for the individual Stick pieces in case they turn out to be needed, for whatever reason. I have always had success printing the 'full set' of Sticks.  
-mike-

remixed_from.author: schlem
remixed_from.title: terraPin, a 120 Film Pinhole Photography System

description.text:
The terraPin 6X6 is a pinhole camera for 120 film with a 6X6 frame, in a square format. This design consists of a slide-in replacement extension that changes the focal length of the pinhole camera. This affects "shutter speed", angle of view, and, possibly, depth of field. Designed for 0.22mm diameter pinhole
f/115 center, f/132 nominal
Horizontal and vertical angle of view: 95.6° This is a "fast", wide-angle extension for the terraPin 6X6. The Incher slides into the camera body with the terraPin Slider system. The shutter is a captive sliding vane that allows for easy control over exposure. The recessed design prevents interference if you prefer to uncover/cover the aperture with your fingertip. Because of the short "focal length" of this extension, there is significant light "falloff" at the edges of the frame and the corners in particular. The geometric center of the frame is f/115, and a 14mm ring radiused around this point is f/132, which gives a good compromise between the frame's extremes of f/115 - f/172 (see diagram)

Instructions There are only four pieces to this extension, and assembly should be obvious from the exploded diagram. You will need:
0.22mm diameter pinhole in thin metal stock
2 X 10mm-long 3mm bolts and nuts (I used countersunk-head bolts for maximum clearance in the field of view -you will need to countersink the holes in the top trim ring)
misc finishing and shaping tools (files, sandpaper, X-acto, etc) I recommend that the inside surface of wide angle extensions be painted with a flat black to avoid internal reflections and ghosting on your exposed film.

title: Prusa I3 Hall Effect  Z endstop mount

description.text: I have a very low Z on my Prusa I3 so I designed this Hall-O holder to fit in the limited space since I couldnt find one already made. I glued the magnet to an existing adjusting screw I had on my machine, but it can be mounted as you want. The clamp works with the very limited space between the smooth rod and motor coupler on my machine. It's working great and I get a much more consistent z height over using a micro switch.
I used ABS, but imagine any plastic will do. Printed on a MendelMax 1.5.

Stabilize your Nerf jolt with this super simple 2 part print. In between the two pieces you will need to glue a 13 inch rod with a diameter of 16 mm. It can be a wooden or plastic rod. I wasn't able to find any rods with a diameter of 16 mm online, but I was able to find one with a diameter of 19 mm. This one would work if you shaved down the ends to 16 mm. Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KRLjjmkekFE
19mm rod: http://tinyurl.com/nsu75qq

We have a few Bridgeport vertical mills here at school and we are trying to utilize the 5 S's of Lean Manufacturing by creating a more organized work space.  It took a few tries to fit the holder to the mill perfectly, but it should fit with a press fit.  Each mill had some dimensional variations from 1-2 mm.  The model is nice and rigid and holds the handle quite well.  
Printed with a 0.3 mm nozzle at a 0.15mm layer height.  Ultimachine Black PLA extruded at 200 degrees.

title: Scythe Motor Mount for UDI U816 Quadcopter

description.text:
The supplied cage for my quadcopter was too large, taking it off left me too vulnerable to bumping onto things, which can really mess up your flying. So I designed these.   
They are small, light, offer a degree of protection from bumps, and most importantly, they are really, really good looking.

These will require much of the copter to be disassembled, as the wires run through them. Not something I would recommend unless you are comfortable with un-wiring and rewiring the copter.  
I flipped two of mine before printing. Otherwise all the hooks will face the same way.

comments.text: Do you have a solidworks file?

This is my first attempt at remixing an object in blender. I felt like representing New Mexico. This is a remix of Starno's penny opener with teaguejg's zia symbol. This is still a work in progress.  print at 100% fill with support for best results.

I made mine on a slightly modified solidoodle 2. print at 100% with support. I noticed while it was printing there was a void between the zia and the penny slot, but it still hasn't broken after about 100 opens.

author: famin

description.text: Fireangel Wheel

This is a ( crude) replacement for part A5 of a Tamiya Thundershot.  A5 joins the front gearbox to the bumper and supports the lower arms of the front suspension.  It's prone to cracking especially if the bolts have been done up too tight.  This one was printed at 5% density and is yet to break.  This print might not last long and is only a temporary measure while waiting for an aluminium replacement.  
OpenSCAD source is included if you wish to edit the tolerances and re-generate the STL.

description.text:
As a long time Leatherman Charge owner I found two great things on Thingiverse and decided that what I really wanted was something that combined them both into a single toolkit.  
This thing only contains the modified part, for the accessories you need to go to the parent parts and download them from there.  
Be careful when printing this, the model has the handle clip and tool holder as 'separate' parts, some slicers deal with this kind of mashup OK, but you may need to adjust the settings to ensure it prints correctly as a single part, after slicing check the interface area between the clip and body, if you see unbroken infill then it has sliced OK, .

This is a fully parametric, fully printable, quadrocopter frame design done with Inventor. With this design you can print a quadrocopter with a 160-260mm motor to motor distance, giving enough room to accommodate props from 101.6mm (4") to 177.8mm (7"). Motivation: I wanted to build a quadrocopter which I could use to learn with, a basic requirement of this being that I need to be able to fix it with minimal cost and difficulty. So its a good job I have a 3d printer! Draft: I started this design with the intention of squeezing all the electronics into the centre of the hub area, in the same plane as the arms. I completed a draft with this in mind, but I wasn't happy with how much plastic it consumed and I also hadn't given any though to how I would route cables around the frame. In addition to this, I based the design on "guestimate" dimensions, it was always going to need some sort of reworking. Revision 1 (Pictured): The draft design gave me some good ideas to move forward with, it also gave me the confidence to buy the parts I'd need to eventually get this thing into the air. For this revision I moved the electronics to a more standard location on top of the hub area. There are fixing holes for the electronics on a square of 45mm about the centre, this can be varied. Another variable dimension is the motor to motor distance, which for this revision is set at 180mm allowing for a 10.16-12.7mm (4-5") prop. With this revision I gave a little thought to routing of wires and came up with the "power layer". This component stacks with the hub of the quadrocopter and allows the esc's and battery to plug into the frame. Many quadrocopters suffer from the "flying spaghetti monster" problem, this solution goes some way to alleviate that. This is the design I have printed, as it turns out I was being a bit ambitious with the prop size, all things accounted for it weighs about 450g. I calculate about 600g of thrust with this set up meaning its going to have to run at over 3/4 throttle to fly. Whilst not a show stopper its certainly going to strain the motors and esc's, and I doubt its going to be manoeuvrable. Landing gear has also been added, not sure how it will perform but it certainly looks the part. Revision 2: This design incorporates some lessons I learned from the previous revision. The arms are thinner, making them lighter per unit length, and allowing for greater prop sizes up to 177.8mm (7"). The thinner arms also mean the hub area uses less plastic, more weight saving. The minimum thickness of all components has also been reduced slightly in an attempt to remove some more redundant plastic. Due to the allowance for larger props I hope to achieve over 1kg of thrust with this design, giving much more acceptable performance. Major Dimensions:
motor_to_motor = Distance between motor centers, dictates arm length which is limited by build platform size.
arm_width = Self explanatory
arm_height = Self explanatory
mounting_square = The side length of the square who's corners lie at the center of the mounting holes.
hub_square = Width of the hub.
pinch_gap = Width of the gap between the top and bottom hub components.
power_thickness = The max thickness of your power distribution circuit.
battery_width = Self explanatory
battery_thickness = Self explanatory
structural_cover = The minimum thickness of any section. Please take note, I havent flown this yet. I ordered a receiver that as incompatible with my transmitter and am waiting for a replacement from chine (boo). I shall update this thing with pictures and hopefully videos when I get the last bits in place. I'm open to any suggestions as to how I can improve this design further. Moving forward, I'm going to experiment with different thickness's in an attempt to find a good trade off between weight and strength. Electronics Supplemental
Some info on the electronics was requested. There is an awful lot of choice in this respect, you ultimately need to decide on a control unit and a drive system. For my control unit (not pictured) I use an Arduino nano, "All in one" sensor board which can be found on ebay, and a fly sky 6 channel receiver (FS-R6B) to go with my fly sky transmitter (FS-TH9X). Such a control system will work for any quad configuration. The drive system is dependent on the quadrocopter weight and maximum allowable prop diameter, this choice is non trivial and I suggest you visit some quadrocopter forums where you will find a huge amount of sadvice and suggestions. There is a wealth of further information at Aeroquad.com and multiwii.com

I have uploaded 2 zip files, one containing the Inventor files and one containing STL files for the current final configuration. If you are unable to edit Inventor files and wish to have changes made to the design please ask in comments. Print
4x arm
1x hub_top
1x hub_bottom
1x power_layer
1x battery_mount
2x landing_gear There's nothing too drastic to print here, no overhangs, just some slightly thin walls. When printing the arm and landing gear, make sure you have them angled 45 degrees across the build platform so that they fit. At 25mm/s feed rate I printed a full set in about 6-7 hours Clean Up
To keep everything strong this is designed with zero tolerance for fits, your going to have to either calibrate your machine and add tolerances or file the parts like I did. Assemble
Hopefully its obvious how this goes together, 4 arms are inserted into the hub top and bottom, the power layer and battery mount stack underneath this. Secure with bolts(m3x30 bolt diameter is variable) and nyloc nuts. For the power distribution circuit I used 2mm (variable) male bullet connectors which are secured in their groves with epoxy. The bullet connectors, battery connector and electronics power connector are wired to 2 copper plates one for positive and one for negative. The copper plates must then be insulated from each other. There is a gap allowed for the battery connector and electronics power connector to enter the power layer, the size of this gap is variable. Landing gear slots onto the battery mount, you can either force fit this or add some epoxy. I would suggest mounting the electronics with vibration damping stand-offs. The motor mounts are designed for the 3 bolt mounts I have. I'm happy to knock up a more standard 4 bolt version if its requested.

title: Very Simple Case for SainSmart LCD Smart Controller 12864

description.text: This is a really simple case for the SainSmart LCD Smart controller 12864.  It's very minimal.  It has a top and bottom and you just push it together and the friction between the two ought to hold it together for you.

Attached is a OpenSCAD file in case you need to tweak it.  I tried to comment it well.  There is a module for the front case, back case, knob, and two buttons.  The shorter button is meant to be used for the emergency stop.  
I had some issues with the original measurements because I believe that the PLA shrank when it cooled, so you'll find the measurements are slightly different than if you measure the controller with a caliper. If you print the whole thing, it uses very little material so you might want to print it and tweak the OpenSCAD file yourself if you have different shrinkage rates than me.

author: dcengr

description.text:
I have always wanted a small “Pocket Smartphone Tilt Stand” that I could carry with me in a pocket, or leave laying around at home or at work on a table or counter, so it would always be available whenever I sit down to use my Smartphone.  
The Stand needed to be small enough and light enough to carry easily in my pocket or my wife’s purse so as to always be available wherever we are.  
With these goals in mind, I created this small “Pocket Smartphone Tilt Stand”, which works with most tablets, as well. This model also scales easily.  I print it at 100% for most Smartphones; at 150% for small tablets; and at 200% for larger tablets.  
They print quickly and require very little post-print finishing.  I print mine in PLA, but I think ABS might produce an even better model.  
Since they print quickly, and are so useful, you may want to print extras to give to friends and family as small gifts.  I printed mine in Black, but my wife likes the Light Blue and light Yellow ones I printed for her.  
I print these using the following settings: Resolution=”Standard”; InfIll=20%; Shells=4; Layer Height=0.15mm; Raft=On.  They all turn out well, and require only a tiny bit of post-print finishing on the “bottom" end (as printed).  
Have Fun printing and using one or more of these small Tilt Stands, and please let me know of any improvements I should consider.  
-mike-

I print my versions on a MakerBot Replicator 5th Gen printer with settings as follows: Resolution=Standard; InfIll=20%; Shells=4; Layer Height=0.15mm; Raft=On. They have all turned out very well, and required only a tiny bit of post-print finishing on the “bottom" end (as printed).  
Use your Slicer's "Scaling" capabilities to make the stands longer, wider, or taller to suit your needs or preferences.  I print mine uniformly scaled to: 100% for most Smartphones; to 150% for small tablets; and to 200% for larger tablets.  
I considered adding a non-slip bottom to the stands, but I find that my cases provide enough friction, and that leaving them as printed in PLA allows them to slide easily on a table adds to their utility for my uses. I have a silicone case on my iPhone, so the stands 'cling' to the iPhone while sliding easily with the phone as it is moved slightly on the table. My wife’s iPhone with a leather case also works well.  Your mileage may vary.  
Suggestions are welcome.  
-mike-

comments.text: I'm pleased that you got it to work, and hope you find it as useful as I do.  I use mine virtually every day at breakfast and lunch and many times at my desk.  It's probably the most useful model I've made.  With my 'silicone' Apple case, it 'sticks' to the back of my iPhone 6+ pretty well, and I find myself sliding the phone around quite a bit to avoid bright light reflections.  For a less 'sticky' case the rubber feet you suggested would be a great addition.  For the rough end I used a small piece of sandpaper and got it smoothed out pretty quickly.  I could remove the 'fillets' from one or both ends and it wold print without needing any post-print finishing, but I didn't want the sharp edges in my pocket.  Perhaps smaller 'fillets" would work better?  I wonder what layer thickness and how many shells you used to print it.  -mike-

title: super simple universal Filament Spool block

description.text:
I designed this because I couldn't print one of those one-piece frames that hold the 608 bearing on my TinyBoy. uses:
  • 4 x 608 bearing
  • 4 x 8mm round wooden dowel
  • 4 x Filament Spool block
    • The big hole fits the 608 skateboard bearing's 22mm diameter
    The small hole fits the 8mm round wooden dowel from Lowe's or HomeDepot cut the dowel length to your desired spool size, insert into the small hole, insert the 608 bearing, then insert 2 more dowels into these bearings. its a tight press fit, so you can slide the dowel rod in or out to fit the size you need. description.text: An arm to mount a Logitech C270 webcam to the bed of a Robo 3D printer. Perfect for monitoring prints with OctoPrint! Video of the mount and camera in action: https://youtu.be/1TroQwgVaAQ
Print out both the camera mount arm and the spacer block.

Hook the arm over the Y axis carriage just to the left of the center bed support and line the hole up with the one in the right side of the Y carriage. Slide the spacer block into the pocket one back side of the carriage where the hole is. Use a 1-1/2" #6 machine screw and nut to secure the arm and spacer block through the hole in the carriage.
Use a couple of zipties to secure the camera to the end of the arm. There are two mounting options allowing you to secure the camera to either the horizontal or vertical face of the arm.

title: Companion Cube Multiple Parts for Printing
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: While the original printed without to much sag from overhang it became more noticeable at larger scales so I thought why not slice it into 3 parts and acetone it together later?

Note: Files are scaled rather large. If you want to print a smaller cube remember to scale all three parts by the same amount! Note: If you normally print with a high number of solid exterior layers you will want to remember to turn it down our you may end up with an almost solid cube. I normally print with 5 exterior layers for structural parts and forgot to turn the number down.... Note: You can choose to print A and B as either solid or 'Hollow' (8cm plug removed from the center) A: x1
B: x1
C: x2 (Top/bottom)

comments.text: The Hollow ones need to be scaled the same as the others. Also It would be cool to have a version that is split into 8 smaller cubic segments to allow for printing larger companion cubes on small printers.

This mount will allow you to place your Gopro just about anywhere and easily be removed when you're done. You just need to make inch wide straps with fasteners that can be tightened to size.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IeWrAQvrb1M Making it and putting it all together:

This is a 3D printed magnifying glass printed using an SLA printer using clear resin. (Form1+ from Formlabs). After support removal and cleaning, use about 5 thin coats of a crystal clear enamel spray. This will reduce layer visibility and greatly increase clarity of your lens. Be careful where you store this, in direct sunlight this lens will focus enough solar energy to start a fire. Absolutely no sanding or polishing was performed on this print. The clear enamel will do all the work for you. Be sure to hang-dry the lens for a day or so because resting the lens while the enamel is not fully cured will leave marks on your lens. I can't tell you any of the optical measurements because I just guessed at it for this proof of concept. Video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x3NXvE6GcOU Image Gallery:
https://imgur.com/a/7xttX

Clips can be slippery. I replaced the tiny platform clips (15mm wide (.59")) supplied with the Afinia machine with larger ones (called "Binder Clips" 19mm (.75"), maybe $2 for a dozen), but even those slipped out of my fingers once in a while. These files are for those two sizes. It may be possible to scale the to fit other size clips. My settings were: 0.20mm Z-rezolution. "Fine" quality. With a raft, and printed right-side up. Small, thick prints hold heat and are often improved with fan cooling. I definately recommend cooling in this case. Let the raft(s) go down hot and sticky, and then turn on a fan. To assemble:
Remove a spring-wire from the clip (just squeeze its sides together).
Fit the grip pad into it, oriented correctly.
Reattach the wire to the clip.
Attach to the end of your blind string when the original dongle breaks!
Print Standing on flat side. Remove flat side afterwards. Insert string, tie knot and voila. You may need to drill out the hole if your string size or print settings do not match.

title: HS1177 camera mount for Blackout Mini H Quad

description.text: Camera mount for Blackout frame with adjustable tilt. Will not fit the stock nylon hex spacers, you need 5mm round spacers. Works with HS1177 and other similar sized cameras with cases. Print 2 washers and the mount itself, use washers to improve camera friction with the mount. Use double sided sticky tape between the mount and the PDB or use M3 nylon bolt with a nut through the center hole. This design is based on ZMR250 camera mount by @czuryk. Thanks! For Blackout frame only, will not work on ZMR250 because of the different distance between the front spacers.

One surplus AT4 (Bazooka) used + PVC PIPE + 3D Printer = Dangerous Fun Experimental way to convert a used Bazooka Tube into a unique Firework artillery shell launcher. 3D printer can make you some semi useful stuff like whistles or bottle openers, but lets look deeper. Personal 3D printers give you the ability to make custom high precision parts quickly. Allowing you to combine two parts into one Assembly for maximum fun! Primary Test video (A Must Watch!) http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TUdNGFR3cIw Previous Life: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h6Gq0GCP3BU

Acquire: 1 X 2" PVC PIPE (12"~20")
1 X 2" PVC CAP
1 X Bazooka Top V1 (Printed)
1 X Bazooka Bottom V1 (Printed
1 X Used Bazooka (~3.3" ID)
1 X JB WELD
1 X PVC Cement
1 X 200 grit sand paper
1 X Knife Instructions:
1) Print both Top and bottom Bazooka Parts.
2) Check if both parts side snugly on 2" Pipe (Sand parts till they do)
3) Glue 2" cap onto 2" Pipe (Allow to dry)
4)Slide Bazooka Bottom all the way to the bottom of the 2" Pipe (Jb weld in place)
5)Slide Bazooka top 2" From top (Jb weld in place
6)Paint tube if desired. Add Orange ring around the from to identify this is not A real Bazooka Warning: These machine was build by trained professionals with years of experience. This machine is still experimental and it is strongly advised not to build this. Fireworks are not toys and should be used based on instructions provided with them. I will not be held liable if you build this.

This Soprano size ukulele is a 3 piece design:
  • Body
  • Fretboard
  • Bridge
    • It has no conventional headstock i.e. headless, in order to minimize overall length. Instead, the tuning pegs are located at the tail end. It has a groove in the neck to accommodate a neck rod to stiffen it as most 3D printed plastic is too bendy under string tension. Use something like this for the in-neck rod: http://www.acpsales.com/.125-x-.325-Rectangular-Rod.html Also it is meant to be fitted with simple friction tuners like this: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00E3UA3JQ You can hear/see a demo of it on Youtube https://youtu.be/MWWb5VRRV_g
OpenSCAD

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/lHjQQKoAvWi

Updates
09/07/2016: Global update after one year production. Now setup in 4 plates ready to print. This is the bowden version. In onshape exists direct extruder version too.
11/12: Now XY_bearings_R is fix.
11/7:: ramps support internal. a little less plastic to print. new printed cube. now with 3 holes to put 3 m3x20 in. It makes your cube as solid as aluminium version ! definitely.
10/23: bom added. sorry for the delay.
10/06: new motor support right to align better and be more consistent with the left one. Some little changes in all models to help ease of assembly. 09/18: Bigger pulley_608 hole, smooth Xrod_support and endstop, new XY_bearings_LR for easier assembly, add slit on Z_slide and bigger nuts hole on Y_Slide_LR 09/16: Add idler_pulley and new XY_bearings R L 08/27: scalu_Y_rod_motor_support_R was missing. good now.

Here is our last SmartrapCore evolution :
The SmartrapCore ALU! http://smartfriendz.com/en/home/54-smartrapcore-alu.html Now aluminium profiles are becoming mainstream , we can enjoy the more modern look, the assembly benefit , thanks to hammer nuts, and the stability in time of aluminium. Like all our designs, this model is full , active, open source and you are welcome to build one.
The assembly documentation is on youtube : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KQFCcp26U0U&list=PLOC55t9dY7y94dfJ4VI-5qbKi7heZsKoJ the realtime 3d model is on sketchfab ( very usefull for asswembly ) . We are working on putting all screws and accessories in it, so eventually you would need only that to assemble the printer : https://sketchfab.com/models/10d76d1f459f489ab546df174f1a9d0b This model was designed in onshape :
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/086229ea796640d29acd68ff/w/2030a3358fd641da896d20a5/e/1e4ef00263ee4eae9316731a We , at smartfriendz, found this new CAD software the best solution to share our open designs . Everybody with a little learning path will be able to copy it and modify simple things , or make new accessories. The Smartrapcore standard is still active and you will find the new version of the design ( evolution ) in the very same onshape document. Only the openjscad version will not be updated.
The ramps support on the side is there : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:258602

title: Handle for jig saw blade T-SHANK

description.text:
This handle has a cutout for a jig saw blade. Will use any t-shank jig saw blades. I don't have a printer yet, but I made this out of wood and used it for pumpkin carving. You will need some kind of glue or jb-weld to keep the shank in the handle. For pumpking carving you want the bigger, more spaced out teeth. The close teeth clog up quickly. This should be usefull for lots of other things. If you want to put a slot in a different handle, it wants to be .05" wide by .32" tall with a cut .85" deep in to the handle. There is a little more to the shape, but it should be solid enough with glue. Just realized Buckeyball made a similar thing but with replacable blades.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12867

2mm acrylic case cut on a laser cutter for a Nanode (http://www.nanode.eu/ and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7463). Designed to be small, light and able to have a removable lid. There are two models, one that is simply a case the other has a base that include mounts which allow the Nanode and case you be attached to a wall. The design allows all the parts to be cut on an A4 size sheet of 2mm acrylic. The height of the case allows for headers to be used and supported by the case, meaning shields can be used nicely. The design works well with 3mm thick material too but you need to move the tabs out by 1mm to make it all fit nicely. If you don't feel like moving the tabs out it still works well however. Equipment needed:
1 x A4 2mm thick acrlic/perspex
2 x M3 12mm Screws or M3 12mm Socket Cap Screws
2 x M3 Nuts
3 x M2 10mm Screws
12 x M2 Nuts
4 x 6mm rubber feet (optional)
and a small amount of Super Glue

1) Open the dxf and delete the base plate that you do not want.
2) Arrange the parts accordingly to fit on to the A4 sheet.
3) United lines (it will make cutting faster) and Cut.
4) Arrange the parts and layout in preparation for assembly.
5) Glue sides and base plate together and leave to dry.
6) For each M2 screw: screw on one nut, push through Nanode mounting hole, screw on two more nuts.
7) Place Nanode in to case - it is tight fit to get the screws in.
8) Use last three screws to fix Nanode to base plate.
9) Push M3 screws through lid and hand screw nuts on to end of screw.
10) Place lid on case by having lid slightly to one side then sliding across so that screw and nut slide in to gap.
11) Attach rubber feet to base plate.

Do the same for the servo_mount (see picture) furthermore i modified the rudder_mount: In the tube for the rudder i glued a 4mm copper tube (inner diameter 3mm) with epoxid so i can use a long M3 screw for the mechanics.

using a Replicator2x
the Rudder i printed standing up, very slowly (15mm/s outlines ) and 20mm/s infill/insets. support on, 50% infill. 2 shells
for the Servoarm i used the same settings. they are small. you need to print three of them.
For the mount i increased the speed to 25mm/s and 30mm/s respectively, and 30% infill.

title: Holder for eddy current probe with spring

description.text:
Eddy current probes are used in non-destructive testing of metals.
It basically is a small pick-up coil excited by an ac current and produces an alternating magnetic field. When the probe tip is placed on the metal surface the eddy currents generated in the metal change the properties of the pick-up coil. These changes can be used to find out e.g. the presence of cracks in the metal or can be used to measure the thicknes of paint layers on the metal. (see e.g. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eddy_current). The effect is also used in inductive proximity probes in e.g. 3D printers. In my application I scan the probe by a motorized stage and move it until it slightly touches the metal surface. The probe holder reduces the force on the surface when the probe is touching by using the bending of the thing plastic spring holding the probe. At the moment the actual force on the surface is not measured. This could be added by including a strain gauge on the spring. To be done later ...

The holder is printed in one piece without support with the thin spring part pointing upwards, I printed the holder using PLA with a 0.2 layer height without support on a simple da Vinci Jr. 3D printer. The spring blade is 2 layers thick.  
The four holes in the top plate are used to mount the holder to the extruder head of an old 3D printer.  
The enclosed FreeCAD script file can be used to adapt the design.
